Should the government even be involved with 'nudging' us? I thought we were a Free people, once...

I am not a test tube, or a academic study - I am a free person, created by God, with certain inalienable rights. It may take a 2nd Revolution to restore those rights, but if that is so, then so be it. In your academic studies...please understand in most of America (outside the liberal city Enclaves) we do not want government telling us how to think - we think it should be the other way around.

Michael: I disagree. Worse comes to worse, the government (or whoever) is justified by "scientific authority" to control citizens. This leads to even more control since it is "empirical" (which doesn't mean much, really). Sciences are co-opted (or more likely "funded" in a certain direction, which happens anyway). I don't think the result is as harmless as you may imagine. Even though I am politically quite liberal, I don't think the governments role is to make us "better people". There's a lot more pressing problems that are more immediate.

Do you agree with warnings on cigarette packs because there has been enough research to prove them true?
Do you care that private business interests lie and lie and lie? Do you care that private business interests misrepresent research?

Although it may be true that much of this is "empirical research", it must be looked at more careful, especially regarding generalizability.

For example, most of this research is conducted on college students in a limited number of schools, but that is not a diverse or representative population. Second, it is usually conducted in controlled "lab" conditions, not in real world settings. Even if you use the example of "soup on sale" - we need to know where the sample stores were located, in what sorts of socioeconomic and ethnic areas, at what price, time of year, etc. And, this example is limited to soup-buying (a minor purchase decision); what does that say about all forms of decision making?

This may sound like nitpicking, but, as a social scientist myself, I am very very reluctant to have federal policies developed based on limited, specific research. It is not the fact that it is "empirical", that doesn't mean its useful or has what is called "ecological validity" (true in the "real world" in a general sense). Such specific findings are often not appropriate nor sufficient to use as the basis for public policy.

Contrary to the sentiments above, the media has never been LESS concentrated in history than it is now. Besides the traditional broadcast networks and newspapers there are literally millions of other sources of information out there.

People are awash with information (good and bad). What information they seek and find and what they do with with this information is another question. Information quantity or accessiblity is definitely not the issue.

I’m with mancuroc,

RE: “Do we want government stepping in to protect us from our own mistakes?”

RE: “Government could crack down on companies that exploit common cognitive errors to induce you to pay more for your mortgage, bank account, credit card or car warranty.”

I’m fed up with such justifications that legitimate the predatory aspects of our economy—the noted example is precisely Senator Warren’s complaint of “tricks and traps” rigged in deluges of fine print on various types of credit application, let alone the same as we saw with MBSs or CDOs or CDSs—and its Triple A, so trust us.” So, if company A manages fraudulently to pull one over on consumer B, the mistake then lies with the latter, who trust was misplaced and instead should have been more imbued with “buyer beware?”

And this is a basis for an economy? “Buyer Beware!” instead of “Seller Beware!”?

Such exploiting of such cognitive errors as you describe them is whole different kettle of fish from the example of the driver license organ donation or when to change your AC filter—it’s deliberate misrepresentation to the customer (and we still get blinkered rational choice theory nonsense from freshwater economic departments). If a bank dupes me into paying more for a line of credit when their sell was that in fact I’d pay less, the gov’t “cracking down” isn’t being paternalistic; it’s enforcing one of its chief functions of upholding the law and establishing justice.

RWR
OKC, OK

"Individuals may be imperfect decision-makers, but they still possess more information than faraway government rule-makers. If government starts manipulating decision-making processes, then individuals won’t learn to think for themselves"

Come, now. Freeing people from government rules sounds fine on paper, but what it leads to is freeing people with means to exploit those without means.

Speaking of individuals possessing "more information": ironically, one of the freedoms that's very evident today is the freedom to concentrate our mass media into just a few hands, which decide what information is widely available. With less information you have less ability to think for yourself. Case in point - how many voters know that ALEC exists, or how it works to impose boilerplate legislation to the liking of its sponsors on the unsuspecting residents of widely different states? This isn't government manipulating the decision-making process of individuals, it's the private sector.

Any white American who believes that "racism is dead," a thing of the past, is living in a dangerous state of denial. Each of us born before, say, 1980, maybe later, was raised in an environment of racist assumptions and attitudes. They varied in intensity from outright viciousness to more subtle forms. My northern politically-liberal parents taught "tolerance" toward black people - just another, gentler, patronizing kind of racism..

For most older (and some younger) Americans, racism is bred in the bone, whether or not we want to acknowledge it. Each moment, I have to be alert to its subtle presence in my make-up; otherwise I'm its tool. So painful to be honest about one's inherited subliminal racism, but so very essential if we are to live and share as truly decent human beings, free of racism's insidious influence.

When reason and science (including the "dismal" science) plus experience, measurements, statistics, and history all point to one course of action, and when a society (and its government) turns to the opposite direction, once more, we realize that society remains mostly irrational in its decision-making --in spite of all the attempts since the Enlightment to improve our decision-making.

Today's Captains of Industry might seem to rejoice --their manipulation has so far worked and they have convinced society to be overtaken by irrationality. Yet, these very Captains should not feel too cozy. The very same weaknesses that allow a society to turn irrational and be manipulated are the very same weaknesses that result in self-destruction.

Our latest wars, our economics, our ignoring climate change, our foreign policy, even our spin and political conversation and the re-interpretation (mis-interpretation?) of our laws are pointing to one direction: self-destruction.

Our Captains of Industry perhaps might want to be a bit less greedy and a bit more forward-thinking. The very irrationality that allows their manipulation is behind the destruction of empires, and civilizations, of anarchy, and of violent revolution, and the rise of fascism and totalitarianism. For their sake and our sake, a correction in course is a must!

The megabankers deserve the death penalty, nothing less. They destroyed the lives of hundreds of thousands of people, if not millions. By contrast we go berserk and gleefully execute some small-time hood who shoots the local 7-11.

Until the Chief Embezzlement Officers face personal ruin, lengthy imprisonments, and yes, the death penalty for financial crimes, we will continue to see this movie again and again.

I would have to agree with Dagma20 here. Take the filter light example. Without a government requirement, a manufacturer installing the reminder light might be innovative in comparison to its competition, and assuming all other product qualities are equal, that light might encourage more people to purchase that product over another - that's called capitalism and the free market. Where imminent danger is involved, it would be acceptable for government to regulate, out of safety concerns. Mandating these tweaks - e.g., placement of nutritious food in school cafeterias might be acceptable if government money is supporting the food program, but maybe unhealthy options ought to be entirely eliminated, instead of enacting complicated regulations. Take the addition of Chobani in NYS cafeterias, for the opposite but related situation.

Many of the ideas of Milton Freedman are still with us.

We still have his all volunteer army. Milton did away with the draft.

His negative income tax was put in place through reforms in welfare and the earned income tax credit. It may not look exactly like his proposal, but to a large degree it is.

The public colleges are charging tuition, which was another one of his ideas. I think he got that one wrong on several counts.

His libertarian ideas have certainly thrived.

Many of his ideas are not discussed simply because they are not controversial, they are part of our lives.
Well, how would you know what data is useful to the NSA or enhancing to your security?   Would you trust Mr. Snowden with any confidence?

To say "nothing was done that prevented" Tsarnaev is an error. In fact, the questioning he was subjected to further compelled him to act as he felt more anger towards the US once it was finished. I wonder what your feelings would be if, based on suspicion, Tsarnaev were imprisoned before he had done anything. The fact is, this particular episode got through the system. To create a straw man argument by mischaracterizing what occurred is poor form. Especially when you dig a little deeper and find that it actually strengthens the pro-NSA argument by highlighting the fact that Tsarvaev WAS actually caught in its net and he was questioned on multiple occasions!

What about a communication from me, living in Cambridge MA (about a mile from the Tsarnaevs' Cambridge residence, a mile from the Stata Center at MIT where the policeman was killed etc) to a Am citizen family member who has been teaching in Kyrgyzstan for nearly 20 years and who, for the past 4-5 years, has been teaching at a small college run by Chinese Christians in Tokmok, just blocks from the elementary school that Tamerlan Tsarnaev attended 15 or more years ago?

Is that in the database? What would anyone make of it? Meanwhile, we know that the Russian security services alerted US authorities about Tamerlan, but nothing was done that prevented the April 15 bombings.

And what about the killing in May of Todashev - a Chechen acquaintance of the Tsarnaevs, who was living in Florida - by the FBI under murky and still unexplained circumstances?

All of this stinks to high heaven. The privacy of American citizens is being compromised, but in the most recent terrorist attack in the US nothing was done to prevent it and the investigation seems to be a mess.

In my opinion, Snowden did our democracy and our constitutional rights a great favor by alerting us to the existence of massive spying. It seems to me that the amount of data the NSA has is too vast to be the least bit useful.
